oai_dc:dc.dc:title: There’s something about a soldier, from the Nashville Times, 1940
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A captioned photo from the Nashville Times (1940), showing the patriotic group as “the small but most colorful part of Hume-Fogg’s R. O. T. C., as it lined up with lifted chins and straightened shoulders on the steps of the school on Broad Street. Beauty as well as the purely military plays a prominent part in the corp’s general set-up, as evidenced by presence in the above picture of the sponsors, Ann Morrison, extreme left, Battalion sponsor; Doris Grubbs, left, regimental sponsor; Betsey Harrison, center, Company A sponsor, and Jennie Lee Jackson, extreme right, Company B. sponsor. The others, left to right, are Charles Vaughn, color bearer; Battalion Commander Maj. Gay Weber, Staff Sergeant John Greene, Company A. Captain Dick McLaughlin, Company B. Captain Luther George, and Color Bearer Jack Martin.” Forms part of the Nashville Times newspaper collection. 1 digital photo.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hume-Fogg High School (Nashville, Tenn.); United States. Army. Junior ROTC
